pros:
Very accommodating and friendly supportive staff
Flexible
Positive Work Culture
cons: Very limited growth opportunity in regional offices

pros: Great place for work-life balance. Remote work only.
cons: No opportunities to move up the ladder. Also, if you are doing a job where you are doing more than someone with a more "senior" position or title than you, there is no way to request a review of your position and ask for more pay and a similar job title to reflect this. Some people simply move along the pay and title scale because they have been there years, opposed to the actual quality of their work or their abilities to do a "senior" or "Manager" designated role and nobody in HR questions why this is.

pros: Bring yourself to work Relaxed attire Career development Support Decent vacation Fully remote with flexible working hours
cons: Fairly high turnover Last of commercial awareness
Workload is way to heavy and fast

review_title: Truly wonderful cause, let down by an appalling work culture.
pros:
- Fantastic cause that needs to be amplified on a wider stage.
- Amazing families taking part year on year
- Corporate support is incredible
cons:
- Bullying management
- Aggressive approach to fundraising
- Targeted irrationally with a boiler room feel
- Employed as fundraising staff, left feeling under utilized, under supported and as though my skillset had depleted. 

I worked at JDRF and joined under some absolutely amazing management. In fact, the management I joined under were a very big reason for my taking of the position. Sadly the pandemic resulted in many restructures, team changes and redundancies - this is where the problem began. 

I wouldn't recommend working at JDRF in it's current state to anyone. It forced me to a really awful place. Management pretend to care, they clearly don't. From the moment I handed my notice in, I wasn't spoke to, addressed or interacted with by the team director. These are truly actions that make you feel worthless.

Many, many people feel the same way & since my departure I know of many, many other team members who have left.

pros: Is a good cause and work with great families
cons: Some of the leadership team were a bit cliquey

pros: Great research and mission but poorly managed
cons: Culture is horrible, people are horrible. Something is clearly wrong.

pros: Opportunity to make a difference, volunteers and staff
cons: No room to move up, little to know raises.

pros:
As with most organizational restructures, there are those resistant to change but those who have been adaptable and have vision for the reasons behind the restructure have excelled. There are still some refinements to be done, but I truly believe JDRF is working towards a collaborative and supportive work environment. 

The current staff who work in the Vancouver office will win your hearts over. They are passionate, fun, resilient, and have strong work ethic. The driving force behind this small but mighty team is their dedication to the work that JDRF does for the type 1 community. JDRF is determined to find a cure for this disease; there is a reason why JDRF is the leading national charitable funder of diabetes research in Canada.
cons: Work-life balance is an issue, but they are working on making it a priority.

job_title: Senior Fianance Analyst in Toronto, ON
pros: Staff and Senior Management are flexible and open to ideas. Good work life balance.
cons: The area is a bit congested in evening, most staff start at 8 am or even before to leave earlier.

review_title: Most poorly run organization I've ever seen
pros: Most of the chapter staff were fantastic and there were some extraordinarily dedicated and productive volunteers.
cons: Senior leadership is absolutely 100% clueless. This is by far the least talented team I have ever worked with. Their only focus is on self-preservation (keeping jobs that pay them vastly more than they are worth). They know little to nothing about the types of fundraising JDRF does and make nothing but poor decisions based on this  shocking lack of understanding. Up until very recently, JDRF Canada had no useable CRM. The one they have recently implemented is like all of their other systems - an abysmal failure and massive waste of staff time.

review_title: Organization with a lot exciting initiatives and great staff
pros:
Passionate volunteers that make you feel you are part of a family
Talented, determined staff with a lot of creativity
New exciting partnerships happening 
Culture open to change and trying new things
A cause that you want to fight for - easy to get out of bed each day and want to raise funds for
cons: Organization is trying to move a lot of new things at the same time. If you are less open to change, this could be hard.

review_title: Squeezing employees without blinking an eye
pros: Nice office, great benefits, solid HR professionals
cons: Normalizing working above the normal hours despite no overtime, lack of culture and socialization between employees, people take 30 mins for lunch and sometimes less

review_title: Its like working on the titanic.
pros: Flexible working conditions, vacation is decent. Not the worst pay (still below average)
cons:
No room for professional growth, if you want to use your brain don't bother going to work here.
Its run by a series of leadership professionals who have failed up (essentially those that couldn't hack it at their current level but somehow got hired into positions way out of their league)

pros: Small org. If you can make a sound business proposal, often projects are given the "green light" which is great if you're someone who wants to gain more experience.
cons: Flat structure - not a lot of room for advancement.

pros: Helping make a difference for T1D families
cons: This was one of the worst companies I have ever worked at. Right from the top, the company valued the wrong thing, longevity over skill, appearances over action. It was a toxic, poorly run terrible place to work and the best decision ever made to leave there.
